friendlyParamError.type_EMPTY_VAR:
{{location}} {{func}}() was expecting {{formatType}} for the {{position}} parameter, received an empty variable instead. If not intentional, this is often a problem with scope.

+ More info: {{url}}
friendlyParamError.type_TOO_FEW_ARGUMENTS: {{location}} {{func}}() was expecting at least {{minParams}} arguments, but received only {{argCount}}.
friendlyParamError.type_TOO_MANY_ARGUMENTS: {{location}} {{func}}() was expecting no more than {{maxParams}} arguments, but received {{argCount}}.
friendlyParamError.type_WRONG_TYPE: {{location}} {{func}}() was expecting {{formatType}} for the {{position}} parameter, received {{argType}} instead.

reference.cannotAccess:
{{location}} "{{symbol}}" is used before declaration. Make sure you have declared the variable before using it.

+ More info: {{url}}
reference.notDefined:
{{location}} "{{symbol}}" is not defined in the current scope. If you have defined it in your code, you should check its scope, spelling, and letter-casing (JavaScript is case-sensitive).

+ More info: {{url}}

syntax.badReturnOrYield:
Syntax Error - return lies outside of a function. Make sure youâ€™re not missing any brackets, so that return lies inside a function.

+ More info: {{url}}
syntax.invalidToken:
Syntax Error - Found a symbol that JavaScript doesn't recognize or didn't expect at it's place.

+ More info: {{url}}
syntax.missingInitializer:
Syntax Error - A const variable is declared but not initialized. In JavaScript, an initializer for a const is required. A value must be specified in the same statement in which the variable is declared. Check the line number in the error and assign the const variable a value.

+ More info: {{url}}
syntax.redeclaredVariable:
Syntax Error - "{{symbol}}" is being redeclared. JavaScript doesn't allow declaring a variable more than once. Check the line number in error for redeclaration of the variable.

+ More info: {{url}}

type.constAssign:
{{location}} A const variable is being re-assigned. In javascript, re-assigning a value to a constant is not allowed. If you want to re-assign new values to a variable, make sure it is declared as var or let.

+ More info: {{url}}
type.readFromNull:
{{location}} The property of null can't be read. In javascript the value null indicates that an object has no value.

+ More info: {{url}}
type.readFromUndefined:
{{location}} Cannot read property of undefined. Check the line number in error and make sure the variable which is being operated is not undefined.

 + More info: {{url}}

fes.libraryError: {{location}} An error with message "{{error}}" occurred inside the p5js library when {{func}} was called. If not stated otherwise, it might be an issue with the arguments passed to {{func}}.
fes.misspelling: {{location}} It seems that you may have accidentally written "{{name}}" instead of "{{actualName}}". Please correct it to {{actualName}} if you wish to use the {{type}} from p5.js.
fes.misusedTopLevel:
Did you just try to use p5.js's {{symbolName}} {{symbolType}}? If so, you may want to move it into your sketch's setup() function.

fes.welcome: Welcome! This is your friendly debugger. To turn me off, switch to using p5.min.js.
fes.wrongPreload: {{location}} An error with message "{{error}}" occurred inside the p5js library when "{{func}}" was called. If not stated otherwise, it might be due to "{{func}}" being called from preload. Nothing besides load calls (loadImage, loadJSON, loadFont, loadStrings, etc.) should be inside the preload function.

webgl.colinearSidesOrRepeatedVertex: face has colinear sides or a repeated vertex.

shape.vertexBeforeBezierVertex: vertex() must be used once before calling bezierVertex()
